summary: This document consists of three separate letters from Capital One to a customer regarding a secured MasterCard account. The first two letters notify the account holder of policy changes regarding security deposits for credit limit increases, effective October 30, 2015, and January 19, 2016. The third letter, dated March 1, 2016, informs the customer that their card is being reissued due to a potential data breach at a merchant.

events.title: Capital One Policy Change on Security Deposits
events.description: Capital One informs a customer that as of this date, they will no longer offer the option to make additional security deposits to increase the credit limit on a Secured MasterCard.

events.title: Second Capital One Policy Change on Security Deposits
events.description: Capital One sends another notice to a customer reiterating that as of this date, the option to make additional security deposits to increase a Secured MasterCard credit limit is ending.

events.title: Card Reissue Due to Data Breach
events.description: Capital One informs a customer that their card is being reissued with a new number as a precaution because their card information may have been stolen in a data breach at a business where they shopped.

locations: Salt Lake City, UT 84130-0285 (Capital One Services, LLC P.O. Box)
keyFacts: The document contains routine customer correspondence from Capital One bank regarding a secured credit card account.
Two letters announce the discontinuation of the option to increase a credit limit via additional security deposits, effective October 2015 and January 2016.
A third letter, dated March 1, 2016, states the card is being reissued due to a potential data breach at an unspecified merchant.
No individuals associated with the Epstein case are named or referenced in this document.
The document appears to be a financial record from a batch of released documents, but its direct relevance to the Epstein case is not evident from the provided text.
